Award.AwardTitle: Multiscale Modeling and Simulation of Evaporation and Boiling in Graded Micro- and Nanoporous Structures

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Zhang, Yuwen
CBET - 1066917
The objective of the proposed research is to investigate evaporation and boiling in graded micro- and nanoporous structures with pore sizes ranging from 10 nm to 100 microns by multiscale modeling and simulation and experiments. A hybrid molecular dynamics (MD) model that includes continuum model for the core of the nanoparticles and MD model for molecules of the nanoparticles at surface and working fluid will be developed. The transport phenomena in the vapor phase will be modeled using the Direct Simulation Monte Carlo (DSMC). The two-way coupling between the MD and DSMC regions are considered by adding two buffer layers near the interface between these two regions. The coupling factors in the macroscale continuum model will be obtained by modeling momentum, heat and mass exchanges between different phases in the pore-scale model. The proposed hybrid multiscale models represent significant advancements over the existing macroscale continuum models. The state-of-the-art fundamental process models will allow the users of the technologies to search for optimized processing strategies to improve the performance of various two phase devices such as heat pipes. The developed multiscale model can also be extended to analyze transport phenomena in porous electrodes and gas distribution layers of the fuel cells to optimize the design of fuel cells. The simulation model can also be applied to biological and micro- and nanoscale heat transfer. The software will be made available at the e-Resource section of the Thermal-Fluids Central
(https://www.thermalfluidscentral.org/e-resources/)

POR.DRECONTENT:
Due to continuous demands for faster and smaller microelectronic systems, effective thermal management has been, and will continue to be one of the most critical issues to be resolved. To meet the ever increasing challenges posted by the thermal management of electronic systems, innovative and transformative measures must be taken to significantly improve the performance of the two-phase thermal management systems. Such measures will not be possible without thorough understanding of liquid-vapor phase change at molecular, nano- and microscale because the heat transfer performance at the system level is profoundly affected by physical phenomena occurring at smaller scales.

The overall evaporation and boiling heat transfer evaluated at the macroscale system level (~ 0.1 m) are strongly influenced by the physical processes occurring at much smaller molecular and pore (~10 nm - 100 μm) scales. We systematically carried out molecular and multiscale modeling and simulation of liquid-vapor phase change of water and argon using nonequilibrium molecular dynamics simulation, lattice Boltzmann method (LBM), and finite volume method (FVM). Several solvers that use LAMMPS (Large-scale Atomic/Molecular Massively Parallel Simulator) and OpenFOAM (Open source Field Operation And Manipulation) software have been developed and the solvers are freely available to researchers around the world. The water model that we developed was submitted to the developer of LAMMPS at Sandia National Laboratories. Effect of embedding aluminum porous metal foam inside the flow channels of an air-cooled Li-ion battery module was studied to improve its thermal management.The results show that desirable temperature uniformity and maximum temperature were achieved when two-third and the entire air flow channel is filled with aluminum metal foam. 

The research findings were disseminated by publication to archival journals, presentation to the professional conferences, and students' thesis. The PI integrated the research funding to the undergraduate senior and graduate courses. The project helped six graduate and undergraduate students who worked on the project get the deep understanding of the nanoscale liquid-vapor phase change. The understanding of liquid-vapor phase change at atomistic and molecular level will also be helpful to understand multiphase phenomena fuel cells and batteries. The developed software will provide tools for the scientific and engineering community to solve problems that they encounter. The PI visited Rock Bridge High School in Columbia, Missouri to give presentation about heat transfer research in University of Missouri. We also hosted a high-school summer intern to work on data processing for the project.   


Last Modified: 10/31/2015
Modified by: Yuwen Zhang
